Kamome decides to infiltrate the school, working undercover under the disguise of a janitor. Soon he realizes that powerful figures from a corporation that Kimiko's family is part of are not about to give up, and his life is in danger as well...

Jonason is a Japanese-style adventure, without puzzles and with menu-based interaction. The interface is point-and-click, meaning that instead of the more typical omnipresent fixed menu commands the player first clicks on an object and then chooses one of the possible actions. There are a few timed sequences, which require the player to perform the necessary actions before the time runs out and the game is lost. The game contains scenes with nudity and sexual situations.

sample_screenshots.caption: This basement door appears to be locked...

title: Jonason: Cugutu no Mai

description:
The beginning of 21th century saw mankind descend into a new Dark Age. Ecological disasters led to rise of terrorism. The planet was engulfed in chaos, and several countries started preparing for a global-scale war. Meanwhile, the restored Soviet Union and Japan began a war of their own, initiating as a conflict over Japan's north-most island, Hokkaido...

Kaien is a doujin (freeware game by independent developer) vertically scrolling shooter. The player controls a lone Japanese jet, making its way through hostile areas, beginning with the defense of Hokkaido and advancing into enemy territories. The enemies include other jets, helicopters, ships, stationary cannons, tanks, and other military vehicles and machines. The player-controlled jet has a basic attack with unlimited ammunition, as well as several powerful attacks of limited usage, such as a fire blast that destroys an entire row of enemies, etc. As in most games of this kind, the levels are punctuated by mini-boss and stage boss battles. Running out of lives results in the Continue screen, forcing the player to restart the level.

sample_screenshots.caption: The helicopter is the final boss of Stage 1

title: Kaien

description:
A terrorist organization known as Slave Dog poses a threat to the entire world. Steel Fox is the name of an all-female special squad, highly trained in counter-terrorist combat. Assisting them is the independent, state-unbound corporation Neo Logic, which produces assault suits -basically giant robots with their own heavy weaponry, which can be navigated by a skillful pilot. The young female pilot Rei from the Steel Fox is sent on a decisive mission, codenamed "Night Slave" - an assault on the terrorist base.

Night Slave is a side-scrolling action game, influenced in setting and gameplay by the Assault Suits series. The player controls Rei in an armored robot, navigating her through hostile areas. The gameplay is heavy on shooting, the stages consisting mostly on fighting one's way through a level, fighting powerful enemies, mini-bosses and stage bosses.

The player finds power-ups of different categories. Some can restore Rei's health, protect her robot with a shield, etc.; others are used to upgrade main and secondary weapons. Weapons can "level up", depending on how many power-ups were spend to upgrade them. The player can choose when and how to spend the power-ups. Weapons are selected before the beginning of each mission.

Extensive cutscenes and dialogues move the story forward between the missions of Night Slave. Some of the scenes feature explicit nudity and sexual situations.

sample_screenshots.caption: The plane will accompany you during this stage. But you spectacularly jump over it...
...They have their own interesting way of... err... convincing people...
Missions frequently begin with such interactive cut scenes, with dialogue and action occurring simultaneously

title: Night Slave

description:
Nikki, the hero of the game, is a cybernetically enhanced young man from the future. His "home time" is the beginning of 22th century; his home town is the international megalopolis Shinjuku City, part of the old Tokyo. Humanity prospers, living in pleasure, relying on incredible scientific achievements. One of them is the time machine. Nikki finds out than four young, attractive school girls from 1994 got involved into some sort of trouble. Using his time machine, Nikki ventures into the past, determined to save them... and expecting a lot of... err... gratitude in return!

Kaiketsu Nikki is an adventure game in essence, with features somewhat unusual for a Japanese representative of the genre. As in most Japanese adventures, the interaction is done via verb commands selected from the menu. The player clicks on an object, which bring up the menu with the commands. However, while there are still no real puzzles, the challenge lies in completing certain actions in time, in order to avoid time paradoxes while staying in the past. The player must explore thoroughly the rooms of the four girls and figure out a way to conquer them.

sample_screenshots.caption: Outside of the Kisshou High School
Not much here but some clothes hangin'...

title: Kaiketsu Nikki

description:
On a cold Christmas night, the male hero of the game enters a large building, hoping to find a warm place. But the elevator he enters is malfunctioning. After a short while he finds himself trapped in the elevator, unable to get out. As his eyes adjust to the darkness, he realizes that a young woman is inside the elevator as well. The two must find a way out, and also learn about each other's lives in the process...

Kurayami (meaning "darkness") is a visual novel concentrating on dialogue and decision-making within the confined setting of a broken elevator and developing relationship between the hero and the young woman. Depending on the player's choices, their relationship will evolve in different ways, leading to different endings.

The game contains scenes with nudity and sexual situations.

sample_screenshots.caption: Trying to find a way out through this wall

title: Kurayami

description:
Kurou works in a company that specializes in "headhunting", finding and recruiting capable employees for big companies. A new client representing a company that has recently concluded a trade with an American software firm needs a new secretary. Problem: the last headhunter who was given a similar request has gone missing. So Kurou's boss wants him to get to the bottom of things, teaming him up with the resourceful and pretty headhuntress Tomoko. Naturally, as the partners begin the investigation, dark erotic secrets of the employees become gradually revealed...

Mesuneko Hishoshitsu is essentially a visual novel. Though there is a rudimentary menu-based navigation in the game, the focus on the gameplay is on making decision rather than interaction with the environment through commands. Some of the decisions lead to premature endings, while others unlock additional scenes (mostly of a sexual nature).

sample_screenshots.caption: Oh, I'm sorry, did I scare you?..
Kids, don't try this at home

title: Mesuneko Hishoshitsu

description:
Ryoko was a police officer, until a tragic accident that happened to her colleague, and the inability of the police force to stop the criminals, has convinced her that becoming a vigilante was a more effective way. Now Ryoko trains to become the best martial artist, taking on the best fighters in the country...

Kakutō Musume Ryoko is structured like a fighting game, but in reality it is primarily a turn-based card game. The game has two modes, Story and Exhibition. The story mode allows the player to control Ryoko between the cut scenes, fighting female opponents as dictated by the story. The exhibition mode allows the player to fight controlling any of the characters that appear in the story mode.

The fights are always one-on-one. The player is dealt a deck of five cards, each representing a certain fighting move (attack, defense, heal, etc.). cards of the same type can be used in an accumulative way, increasing their effect. Attack moves also require the player to stop a rotating list of moves to select a specific move. Winning two rounds leads to victory and continuation of the story.

Between the fights, the actual protagonist of the game (Ryoko's male manager) usually has sex with the defeated girls. The sex scenes are built like a mini-game, in which the player is required to reach a girl's "pleasure bar" by repeatedly tapping a button (or clicking the mouse). However, too intense tapping might result in the protagonist's premature ejaculation, forcing the player to replay the whole scene.

sample_screenshots.caption: What a cool mini-game... don't finish too early, hehehehehe.... :)

title: Kakutō Musume Ryoko

description:
Kanako is a young woman who has just graduated from college and is in a desperate need of a job. Finally, she is invited to a job interview in a large and successful company. However, the boss seems to ask too many personal questions and generally looks at Kanako in a weird way. After she has been introduced to her duties at the new place, Kanako decides to get to know the employees better, and in process learns their most intimate secrets...

The game is a rather standard Japanese-style adventure; the interface consists of a menu with verb commands ("Examine", "Talk", etc.), which usually lead to sub-menus of objects or conversation topics. Navigation is also done via an appropriate menu command.

sample_screenshots.caption: Hmm, two young ladies in the kitchen...
And what are you doing in my boss's office?..

title: Kanako

description:
Based on the anime series Tekkaman Blade. In the year 2087, the Earth is attacked by an alien race known as Radam. Assisting the army of aliens are Tekkamen, powerful armored creatures who turn out to be humans brainwashed by the Radam to further their military causes. Blade is the nickname of one of these Tekkamen, the only one who is able to withstand the brainwashing and help the humans to avert the alien menace.

This interpretation of the anime is a real-time strategy game (RTS). Most of the game consists of large-scale battles between the army led by Blade and the aliens or enemy Tekkamen. The player most order his troops to move, attack, and employ various strategies in real time. Player-controlled army includes plot-related characters (such as Blade himself), as well as "nameless" human troops and robots. Once one of the player-controlled characters is in the proximity of an enemy unit, a semi-automatic battle sequence ensues. During these battles, the player is only able to choose special attacks (if any) for the character in question, or retreat. Otherwise, the character and the enemy will exchange attacks according to their parameters.

Victory conditions vary from mission to mission, but mostly involve defending a certain position or eliminating all enemy troops. Cut scenes between the missions advance the story.
title: Uchū no Kishi: Tekkaman Blade - Orbital Ring Dakkai Sakusen

description:
Revival Xanadu is a remake of Xanadu: Dragon Slayer II.

The remake distinguishes itself with the more detailed, graphically more advanced character portraits and backgrounds in the various places of interest (inns, temples, shops, etc.). Player and enemy sprites are also drawn in a noticeably more detailed way and have a higher resolution.

However, the side-scrolling exploration environments retain the original look, with "retro" graphics reminiscent of the older original game.

For the most part, the location layout in this remake are the same as in the original version, and the gameplay remains largely unchanged as well.

sample_screenshots.caption: and dexterity. Cool pictures, right? But wait till you see...
In the town, people jump on each other's heads :)

title: Revival Xanadu

description:
Three hundred years ago, a great war consumed the world. It is said that people were using devastating magical spells against each other. But years have passed, and the knowledge of magic was forgotten. Legend persists that somewhere there is the Book of Magic, the greatest treasure anyone could dream of. The legend captivated Nash, a young careless thief who decides to ignore the obvious danger and ventures to the borders of the kingdom in search of the treasure. Naturally, he encounters evil forces who won't let him reach his goal; and that's how the thief turns into a hero who will eventually save the world...

Sorcer Kingdom (no relation to the similarly named Genesis/MegaDrive game) can be described as a "pseudo-RPG". The premise and the structure of the game (top-down navigation, vast dungeon-like areas, towns, etc.) imply role-playing elements; however, these are too light to consider the game a "true" RPG. Rather, it contains exploration segments and dialogue alongside action-based battles. The battles aren't very frequent, and can even be set on auto; they are confined to a small area and are triggered whenever an enemy is near the hero. There are no experience points, equipment, or comparable RPG system. The game contains a few scenes with explicit nudity and sexual situations.
title: Sorcer Kingdom

description:
It is said that the country of Suzaku is protected by the spirit of the legendary White Dragon, a mythical benevolent being. A young maiden known as "dragon sorceress" always resides in the temple. Her protectors are young men which are called "sword dancers". One night, the current dragon sorceress, a girl named Setsuna, was attacked by a horrifying monster. Her sword dancer, Hien, tried to save her; but the monster was stronger and flew away with the girl. The young hero swears to bring her back, restoring his honor and the peace in his country.

Sword Dancer has top-down navigation, linear story progression, automatic leveling up, and randomly appearing enemies, which effectively makes it a Japanese-style RPG; however, unlike in most other games of the genre, the battles here aren't turn-based. Taking place on small side-scrolling areas, the battles switch to action gameplay, with the hero being able to jump, duck, and execute different kinds of attacks.

Various characters will join the party, but the player can only control one at a time. Any character can be chosen to be the lead of the party, and hence the active character in battles.

sample_screenshots.caption: Oops... the blue slime is too tough

title: Sword Dancer

description:
Goddess of the Evil Blade is a direct sequel to the first Sword Dancer. The story continues to chronicle the adventures of the "sword dancer" Hien and his mentor, the warrior Tetsuta. They have succeeded in rescuing the "white dragon sorceress" Setsuna from the clutches of the demons. However, greater challenges await the three. Setsuna's life might be in danger, and the watchful eye of the evil Black Dragon continues to follow the heroes. The adherents of the benevolent White Dragon have to prepare for the decisive battle against the forces of evil...

The game plays very similarly to its predecessor. The overall structure corresponds to that of a traditional Japanese RPG: the player navigates the heroes through top-down environments, buying supplies in town, advancing the narrative in a linear way, and fighting enemies to gain experience and level up automatically. Like in the first game, the battles are action sequences that take place in small side-scrolling areas, similarly to fighting games. However, unlike in the predecessor, the enemies are visibly walking on the screen.

The fighting game element is more developed in the second game; two additional modes (beside the main story mode) are accessible from the main menu: "monster attack" and "vs. mode". Monster attack mode allows the player to select one of the game's heroes and fight increasingly stronger monsters; "vs. mode" features two-player competition.

sample_screenshots.caption: Tetsuta is in obvious need of a shave
Byatto takes on a fearsome skeleton

title: Sword Dancer: Goddess of the Evil Blade

description:
Somewhere on the continent of Fandell, there is a kingdom known as Wineslem. For hundreds of years, this kingdom has been enjoying a peaceful life. Its inhabitants make wine from the country's fine grapes, and merchants from all over the world travel there. But the era of piece has come to an end. An evil force that was asleep for thousand years has awakened. Ferocious monsters and terrible disease plague the kingdom. One day, a Wineslem girl named Elphie finds an unconscious young man on the lake shore. He doesn't remember anything about his past. But with his outstanding skills, he might become the savior people are waiting for.

Aiza is an action RPG, somewhat similar in layout to Ys games. However, the combat requires the player to actively press the "attack" key (unlike the "bumping" combat in Ys). Defeated monsters bring experience points, which contribute to the hero's automatic leveling up. Beside physical attacks, the hero can also execute special techniques which require "psyche" points.
title: AIZA: New Generation

description:
Kinbaku no Yakata (meaning "Bondage Mansion") is a sadistic take on the "raising simulation" genre. Two brothers from a decayed nobility lineage live in a dark mansion, specializing in all things gruesome. The protagonist is one of the brothers, who wants to "prove himself" to the other one by kidnapping a young girl and turning her into his sex slave.

The general gameplay is a simplified version of Princess Maker: the player manages a schedule of the victim, which mainly consists of sexual "training" (various sexual activities), as well as more "mundane" tasks as housework. Depending on the player's choices, the parameters of the girl change. The protagonist can also challenge his brother to combat; the outcome of the automatic battle depends on the results achieved when "raising" the sex slave.

sample_screenshots.caption: "It's good not to do anything", she thinks. Pity there is no option to control her and just cut the "protagonist's" throat
I hope they both kill each other...

title: Kinbaku no Yakata

description:
Karei naru Jinsei 2 is a board/dating simulation game, very similar to its predecessor. As in the first game, players can compete against each other or against computer AI in an adult-themed board game, with the eventual goal of having sex with various female characters.

There are more girls and a larger variety of items to buy than in the first game. There are specialized shops (boutique, adult, etc.) which offer more items for sale. The basic gameplay is the same (each player starts a "roulette" which determines the amount of squares he can move on the board). However, an additional "event roulette" has been added, which resembles a slot machine. This roulette influences the player characters' parameters, money, etc.
title: Karei naru Jinsei 2

description:
When a Japanese game's title includes a word that can be understood as "corporal punishment" (shioki), it's not hard to guess the theme of the "story". Basically, the player is cast as one of Satan's minions, who also happens to be the new "punishment teacher" in the Sparta High School. As the protagonist arrives at the school, he quickly attends to his "duties". However, the sadist's efforts are thwarted by a mysterious, masked, completely naked woman. The player's job is to make sure this won't happen again - which means defeating the super-heroine, and continuing to torture young girls...

Kekkō Kamen has elements of adventure and simulation. The player navigates the "hero" through top-down school grounds. Items (mostly instruments of torture) can be collected. When the protagonist is able to capture a victim, he proceeds to torture her; the player is then presented with a point-and-click interface. From time to time, turn-based battles will ensue; however, they are built more like dialogue choices rather than real RPG or strategic fights: the player has to find the right combination of various attacks and the adversary's body parts in order to inflict damage. The simulation element is evident in the detailed torture interaction and in the game's keeping track of the protagonist's "advancements" with his victims and opponents.

sample_screenshots.caption: Point-and-click interface for torture... only Japanese could think of such a thing

title: Kekkō Kamen: O-Shioki Paradise no Maki

description:
In the sequel to to the first Kekkō Kamen, the player is no longer required to control the satanic protagonist of the previous game. Instead, the protagonist is a young substitute teacher (default name Ryusuke) who is perplexed at his discoveries in the high school he is invited to work for. As the title implies (shioki means "corporal punishment"), some teachers and students engage in bizarre sadistic activities. It's up to the player to decide how the new guy will fit in.

This sequel plays more like a traditional Japanese first-person adventure, with still screens, plenty of text, and a basic verb-object interface ("Look", "Think", "Move", etc.). Unlike the first game, the protagonist is not inherently evil here. It is possible to make choices and decide whether he should save the victims or join the torturers. The game keeps track of the hero's alignment, from "demonic" to "angelic" and anything in between.

sample_screenshots.caption: Now this is something you won't see often in a hentai game... the MALE protagonist is raped by a girl with a strap-on!..

title: Kekkō Kamen 2: O-Shioki Densetsu no Maki

description:
Usagi na Panic stars Ramy, a cute bunny-eared female warrior. There isn't much of a story in the game; innocent people and animals require Ramy's protection, and her first mission involves infiltrating a ship called "Pen-Pen", populated by hostile penguins who have gotten themselves into trouble.

The gameplay is traditional side-scrolling action with platforming elements. Ramy's default weapon is a short sword; she can execute dash attacks which damage the enemy but increase her vulnerability. Ramy can also jump (albeit rather slowly) to access higher platforms and avoid attacks. Bombs can be set in order to trap the enemies. The bunny-girl's health is measured (logically) by carrots; eating said vegetable or other food dropped by the enemies increases a unit of her hit points.

sample_screenshots.caption: There is more enemy variety in later stages
Oh wow... can you defeat such a beast?..

title: Usagi na Panic

description:
Kyoko is a young woman who does some counseling in a high school; she must talk to people, listen to their problems, and try to solve them. Naturally, this being a hentai game, the problems are usually restricted to sexual fetishes, and the counseling often consists of helping the patients in such ways that new problems of a similar kind might arise...

The game is a visual novel, with the player's input confined to standard questions about each patient, as well as occasional decision-making, which may or may not trigger particular scenes. There are no persistent verb-based interaction of any kind.

sample_screenshots.caption: Quiet... it will only take a moment
Don't be so surprised... time for work!

title: Kirishima Shinryōshitsu no Gogo

description:
A scientist named Zen Shiratori was investigating the ruins of an ancient Mayan temple, convinced that the proof of the existence of a parallel world lies there. He found a strange glowing orb, which was later accidentally discover by his fourteen-year-old son Gen, who was rummaging through Dad's collection. As a result, Gen was indeed teleported into a parallel world. There, he meets a young girl named Rinna, who tells him that he is, in fact, "Gen-Kaiser", the much-expected savior of their world. Piloting giant combat robots, the two must protect the innocents of that world and defeat evil.

Kisō Shinden: Gen-Kaiser is a turn-based strategy/RPG hybrid (what is commonly called in Japan a "tactical RPG"). There is overworld navigation, and the player can also visit and explore cities; however, these features are rather rudimentary, and hostile areas cannot be explored in real time and are presented as large-scale strategic battles. The characters move in turns over the top-down battlefield and attack when enemies are in range. Animations are displayed for each attack, and experience points are awarded for successful elimination of an enemy.
title: Kisō Shinden: Gen-Kaiser

description:
The protagonist of the game is a young boy who is about to graduate high school and is looking for a job to support himself during the upcoming college years. However, fate intervened and arranged a bike accident, which resulted in a meeting with a creature from another world - a cute fox-girl named Sharan. She needs nothing else but to be together with the hero; but a mysterious voice tells him: "one wish has been fulfilled, two more to go"...

Oh! Kitsune-sama can be considered a visual novel. Though there are instances with the typical "Look/Talk/Think" interaction, it is very limited, there are no sub-menus with objects, every choice is context-related, and the game can be advanced simply by going through all the choices. There are scenes with explicit sexual situations in the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: The fox girl is very direct

title: Oh! Kitsune-sama

description:
The protagonist of the game, a young man named Koichi Kashiwagi, is experiencing strange nightmares, during which he is overcome by murderous impulses. Following the death of his father, he stays in the house of one of his female cousins, with other members of the family also being there. That night, Koichi sees a particularly violent dream, in which he succumbs to his inexplicable beastly instincts and brutally murders a young girl. But the next day her finds out that a girl has really been murdered at exactly the same spot he saw in his nightmare...

Kizuato is an adult, predominantly horror-themed visual novel. Most of the game consists of textual descriptions and conversations superimposed on background graphics and still portraits. The gameplay is limited to occasional choices, which might trigger different scenes. The game uses standard anime-style graphics for the characters, but the backgrounds have a more photorealistic look, mostly in black-white or sepia tones.

sample_screenshots.caption: The adult scenes are scary and repulsive much more than they are erotic
Little girl's bedroom. Note the sepia tones
One of the "choice prompts". What to buy, what to buy?..

title: Kizuato

description:
The hero of the game is a young man who has left his home village when he was six. He remembers four little girls who cried when he left - the most vivid memory of his childhood. Ten years later, he returns to the village to visit his grandmother. The four girls are still there - grown up, looking differently, but still remembering him. But each one of them has a secret, which requires the hero to enter the realm of the supernatural - and perhaps find his true love...

Mystic Princess has elements of a "regular" Japanese-style adventure (interaction possibilities in form of menu-based verb-object combinations), as well as a visual novel (decision-making, different endings). There are also a few places with "pseudo-RPG" turn-based combat, though the main bulk of the game is still dedicated to reading text and "triggering" the narrative. The game has scenes with explicit nudity and sexual situations, usually of a rather "softcore" nature.

sample_screenshots.caption: In the bus, on the way...
This is... a very big tree
Don't cry, princess. I'll be back after 10 years, just in time for a new hentai game

title: Koihime: Mystic Princess

description:
The game has a rather simple premise: the protagonist is a young man who is looking forward to his first day on a new job, that of a teacher at the prestigious St. Erika Girls' High School. Naturally, he won't be busy with teaching alone; the goal is to get acquainted with the various female characters that populate the school, including the nurse and many of the students.

Kōkō Kyōshi: Sei Erika Jogakuin Hen is an adventure game; though following the Japanese design philosophy by offering no puzzles and/or inventory item usage of any kind, it is nevertheless rather open-ended for a Japanese-style adventure. The player is, for the most part, free to visit various locations in the town, including many different rooms in the school, at any time. Interaction with the environment is done in a point-and-click fashion; the cursor changes to eye, face, and hand icon, depending on the object/character it hovers over.

The game contains scenes with explicit nudity and sexual situations.

sample_screenshots.caption: Not all the characters are pretty girls...

title: Kōkō Kyōshi: Sei Erika Jogakuin Hen

description:
The game's protagonist is a young man named Okita. His friend Murakami has recently found a part-time job: housework in the Kuroneko ("Black Cat") mansion, which belongs to a rich and mysterious family. However, since then, Okita hasn't received a word from his friend. Worried about this strange silence, Okita travels to the mansion. There, he finds out that Murakami has left. He decides to stay and investigate the suspicious circumstances. But he is not prepared to the assault of wild eroticism that the mansion's inhabitants will soon unleash on him...

Kuroneko-kan plays mostly like a visual novel, albeit with more choice prompts than it is usually the case in comparable games. The player is sometimes able to choose a location to visit; many other instances require him to choose the correct action and/or answer in order to view an additional scene, or avoid premature death.

sample_screenshots.caption: Outside of the mansion... what a weather...

title: Kuroneko-kan

description:
46 Okunen Monogatari: The Shinkaron (which translates to "The Story of 4,600,000,000 Years: The Evolution Theory") is an unusual role-playing game that puts the player in control of an evolving creature. The playable character is a fish at the beginning of the game; after completing the "fish stage", it becomes a reptile, and so on, until the highest stages of evolution are reached.

Despite this premise, the game retains elements of a "regular" story-driven RPG, with an overarching narrative (the player character is a creature chosen by the goddess Gaia to evolve and protect the Earth), and quest-based structure. The animals in the game can talk to each other, it is possible to chat with friendly NPCs, and the game advances once certain quests have been completed.

The player navigates the heroic creature through (mostly) top-down areas. Hostile creatures are visible roaming the environment. Whenever the player-controlled character touches a hostile creature, a turn-based battle ensues. The battles are viewed from first-person perspective; the player can attack, use special abilities, or flee. Defeating enemies awards "evolution points", which can be distributed to increase the playable character's parameters.

Unlike most Japanese RPGs, 46 Okunen Monogatari allows the player to upgrade any of the four main parameters manually, in any order. These parameters are: attack power, defense, intelligence, and endurance (needed to reduce or eliminate damage received from certain terrain types). Once one of these parameters "levels up", the player-controlled creature evolves into a different, stronger one. The evolution tree for each animal type is rather small, but non-linear, i.e. the player can bypass certain types depending on how he/she builds the character.

The game offers exact descriptions of the animals the hero can turn into, and re-creates real prehistoric evolutionary trees.

sample_screenshots.caption: Wow, look at me, I'm a... "Mostrodon", whatever that is :) Certainly a fine animal :)
Oh wow, look at me. I look... scary :)

title: 46 Okunen Monogatari: The Shinkaron

description:
Long time ago, during the celestial war between the light and the dark heavenly realms, a beautiful goddess statue was sent to promote peace between the realms. However, the dark side used the statue for the opposite purpose. In the end, powerful magic was needed to shatter the statue and finally starting the era of peace. However, the spirit of the goddess is about to be resurrected. Many years later, the young prince Toffeel is dreaming of a present for his birthday, but is sent by his strict father on a mission to exterminate monsters. Soon he becomes involved in the greatest adventure of his life...

Caramel Quest is a traditional Japanese-style RPG with a humorous undertone. The player controls Toffeel and other characters who eventually join the party (up to four). Roaming the top-down world, the heroes fight randomly appearing enemies in first-person perspective, turn-based combat. Characters can also learn and use various magical spells. Some of the dungeons are maze-like and/or contain puzzles to solve.
title: Caramel Quest: Meitenkyō no Megami Zō

description:
The Millennium Science Laboratory is proud to present its most recent and daring discovery: the Energy Shell. A machine that occupies one room can produce an amount of energy that is strong enough even to disrupt time. During the presentation, unforeseen circumstances cause the machine to initiate a time shift, during which the head scientist Stockman and one of his subordinates are teleported to a fantastic world where psyonic powers take the place of technology, and where four different species have co-existed peacefully until the accident. The Dragon Tusk tribe gives shelter to Stockman, but he must undo the time shift, prevent further disasters, and find a way to return to his world...

Different Realm plays like a traditional Japanese turn-based RPG, with party management, world map exploration, top-down view, and automatic leveling up. It also utilizes Glodia's patented combat system, which they also used in their other RPGs, such as Emerald Dragon and Vain Dream: characters are able to move on the battlefield, and the speed of attack depends on the distance between the controlled character and the enemy. The player has to assign initial parameters to the protagonist (Stockman) before the game begins.

sample_screenshots.caption: Dialogue with a... very nice guy, I'm sure :)
Again, note the nice animations in this inn
Characters level up directly after having defeated an enemy

title: Different Realm: Kuon no Kenja

description:
The young Jin has grown up in a quiet secluded hut in a peaceful family, thinking it was his own. But when he turns sixteen, he finds out that he was adopted; on a rainy night, he was found outside of the hut. His mother, dying from numerous wounds, gave his adoptive family a sword and a letter which explained that Jin was destined to prevent a resurrection of an evil demon lord once he turned seventeen. Jin leaves his home and embarks on the perilous journey that will shape his destiny...

Another Genesis is a rather simple and very traditional Japanese-style RPG. The player navigates the hero(es) through the top-down world, visiting towns, buying weapons and armor, descending into dungeons, and fighting randomly (though surprisingly infrequently) appearing enemies in turn-based combat viewed from first-person perspective. The game's graphical and gameplay style are heavily influenced by early Dragon Quest, including a similar interaction menu with options such as "Talk" and "Door".

sample_screenshots.caption: Maybe someone forgot to water him
Random battle against a low-level enemy

title: Another Genesis

description:
The story of Pink Shock Pirates is rather simple: the protagonist is a young girl named Pink, who wants to become a pirate. To do so, she acquires a ship (which she calls Shock), and begins to explore the land in search of crew and adventure.

Pink Shock Pirates is a hybrid of strategy and role-playing. Rather than following a linear narrative with scripted events, the game allows the player to sail through the sea and visit towns on all the continents right from the beginning. Towns are represented by small pictures of places of interest, such as weapon shop, item shop, church, etc. Crew members can be hired in towns, or by performing quests. Instead of a usual RPG "party", the player manages and controls the crew of an entire ship (their number can get as high as 50).

Enemy ships will randomly attack Shock. Before the battle, the player has to position all the crew members on the deck. The player can buy and upgrade the ship cannons, as well as other long-ranged weapons that can be used in battles without engaging in melee. These cannons have limited ammunition; if the player hasn't succeeded to scare the enemy ship away or runs out of ammo, the enemy might get aboard Shock and attack the crew. The battles are turn-based and involve the player moving the crew members on the screen, attacking when an enemy is in range. Attacks are graphically represented as animated sequences appearing in small windows.

Role-playing elements are present in the leveling up of crew members, as well as in the possibility to explore the land on foot. The player navigates Pink over the top-down "world map", entering and exploring hostile areas. Enemies will attack randomly; land battles are handled the same way as the melee combat on the sea.

All the crew members are female, and during combat they might lose parts of their clothes. Despite these suggestive themes, there is no explicit nudity or sexual situations in the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: Take a look at this crew!..
Exploring a beach... and meeting... err... potential crew members

title: Pink Shock Pirates

description:
After the brave pirate Pink has defeated the evil Temujin in the first game, peace was restored in the land of Thanatos. However, demonic forces cannot be annihilated so easily; the spirit of Temujin is still alive, looking for a body to possess once the power of the seal that imprisons his soul is gone. The king of the land is concerned, particularly because Pink herself has disappeared, possibly abducted by Temujin's agents. The king summons four female knights under the command of Sara, and orders them to rescue Pink and stop the forces of evil once again.

Pink Shock Pirates II retains many gameplay elements of the original; however, rather than being a hybrid between two full-fledged genres (strategy and role-playing), it is more of an RPG with strategy elements. Instead of controlling Pink alone and hiring crew members, the player controls a standard RPG party (up to five characters). More gameplay time is now dedicated to exploring the land masses on foot, fighting randomly appearing enemies in turn-based style. Despite the drastically reduced amount of active combatants, the battles still have a strategic edge: the player has to position the five girls on the battle field and navigate them over it, attacking when an enemy is in range. The towns are now viewed from the same top-down view as the rest of the game, and can be physically explored.

Sea exploration and ship customization is still present in the sequel. It is no longer possible to fight with ship cannons; instead, the player can acquire multiple ships. From time to time, a whole armada of ships will attack the protagonists, which leads to turn-based battles that are played similarly to the regular ones, the combatants being represented as separate ships rather than individual characters. As in the first game, the enemies can decide to board the player-controlled ship; a battle with a larger number of combatants (including "nameless" crew members) ensues.

sample_screenshots.caption: When a girl "dies" in a battle, she appears more scantily clad than usually

title: Pink Shock Pirates II

description:
In the magical Sword World, the land of Alantia enjoyed a peaceful existence, until the evil king Ezekiel conquered the land with the help of his demonic minions, and established a tyrannical regime. However, the legend of the Blue Star, a miraculous warrior who would liberate Alantia, continued to live. The last survivor of a powerful race, a young girl named Erina bravely ventures against Ezekiel's forces, in a desperate attempt to fulfill the prophecy.

Alantia is a pseudo-3D scrolling shooter that has certain similarities to Space Harrier. The screen scrolls only if the player character is moving. The heroine shoots energy balls with her staff; in order to shoot, she has to kneel and stop moving. The player navigates the protagonist in different directions, automatically jumping over obstacles.
title: Alantia: Legend of Blue Star

description:
Kyarukan: Super Break Down!! is a simple tile-matching puzzle game with an erotic theme. The player is presented with a grid of tiles containing hidden pictures; the goal is to match identically-looking pairs in as few moves as possible, until all the tiles are revealed and the stage is completed. The player is given a certain amount of lives, which can be increased by revealing special tiles (pictures of a girl's face or the words "life"), or reduced by hitting a tile with a wolf on it. Other tiles that can't be matched include "open" (reveals all the tiles for a brief moment) and "shuffle" (changes the location of the pictures).

Once a stage is completed, the player is presented with an anime-style picture of a young woman. The stages become increasingly complex, with bigger grids and more tile types; the girl gradually removes her clothes after each stage. There are three "scenarios" in the game, with three different girls; however, the gameplay remains identical in all of them.

sample_screenshots.caption: Hey, I'm just an underwear seller

title: Kyarukan: Super Break Down!!

description:
Asuka Akiyama has been an ordinary, innocent Japanese schoolgirl, until a fateful moment changed her life forever. One day, after talking to a nice-looking boy named Ryosuke, Asuka came home and masturbated in the shower. The next day, she found out that someone has taken photos of her during that intimate moment. From that point on, Asuka becomes involved in a violent chain of events. Will she be able to retain her purity and be together with Ryosuke, or put in danger everyone she cares for and become a willing sex slave?

Kyōhaku is a visual novel; even through the game has a rudimentary command menu (with "Look" and "Talk" commands), it appears infrequently, and doesn't allow much interaction. The gameplay involves making choices for Asuka, branching the storyline and leading the game towards one of the many possible endings, only few of which can be classified as "happy".

sample_screenshots.caption: Asuka is not used to do her new "work"
Asuka engages in more hardcore activities

title: Kyōhaku

description:
The plot of Kyōiku Jisshū: Joshi Kōsei Maniacs is rather simple: the protagonist is an ordinary Japanese man named Shingo, who is about to become an intern in a prestigious school. There is only one thing that makes the young man slightly nervous: all his students will be girls. And if that weren't enough, some of his new co-workers are young attractive women. Will Shingo concentrate on his job or succumb to the pleasures of the flesh?

The game is a very simple, low-interaction Japanese adventure. Every screen has four commands: "Look", "Talk", "Move", and - depending on the context - "Teach" or "Go Home". Each day is divided into morning and afternoon sections. The player must repeatedly visit different locations in the school in order to trigger events and advance the story.
title: Kyōiku Jisshū: Joshi Kōsei Maniacs

description:
The third high school year is about to begin, and Takashi Kurosaki decides that it should be a memorable year - at least from the point of view of romantic adventures. His best friend asks Takashi to help him win the heart of Rie, a girl whom Takashi liked in junior high school but hasn't seen much since. However, when Takashi meets Rie, he begins to realize that he may have feelings for her, and is torn between friendship and romance.

Love Escalator is a visual novel with light dating simulation elements. Most of the game consists of anime-style pictures accompanied by text. The game is divided into days; every day, the player can choose dating activities for the protagonist. There are three main heroines, and the player can choose which one to take on a date. Depending on the concrete choice of activities, the girl's fondness of the protagonist will increase or decrease. It is possible to go to cinema, art gallery, bar, or a "love hotel", where the girl may agree to have sex with the protagonist if she likes him well enough. Most of the explicit sex scenes offer additional menu-based interactivity (choice of sexual positions) and are animated.

sample_screenshots.caption: The obligatory sex with an underage girl
What are you laughing at, dude?
Rie in a beautiful Chinese dress, at night. Lovely sky!

title: Love Escalator

description:
In the year 1999, humans have discovered an alien technology that allowed them to construct powerful mechs and ships that traveled faster than light. Ten years later, the Zentradi, a race of proxy warriors serving the ancient Protoculture, encountered the humans during an enemy pursuit. Led by the relentless Britai Kridanki, the Zentradi forces initiate a Space War, trying to harness the humans' nuclear technology.

Chō Jikū Yōsai Macross: Remember Me is based on the anime series Macross. It is a turn-based strategy game in which the player controls an army of space vehicles and mechs operated by humans navigating the giant starship SDF-1 Macross. The game develops linearly, with cutscenes featuring main characters from the anime taking place between and during missions. The player has to outfit Macross with mechs, ships, and weapons before each mission. Afterwards, the player positions the combatants on the battle field. The player then navigates ships and mechs on the screen, engaging enemy craft in combat. Combat sequences proceed automatically, and are displayed as animated sequences.

sample_screenshots.caption: You and what army?!... Oh, you mean THAT one?..
I don't understand whatcha guys are sayin'

title: Chō Jikū Yōsai Macross: Remember Me

description:
The year is 2009, and humanity's most powerful weapon is the Super Dimension Fortress One, also known as "Macross", an alien starship containing powerful technology. On a fateful day, a fleet of an alien warrior race known as Zentradi was hit by Macross' automatic defense system, inadvertently starting Space War I.

Chō Jikū Yōsai Macross: Skull Leader is based on the anime series Macross, narrating its initial chapters and focusing on one of its primary characters, Hikaru Ichijyo. Like Remember Me, it is a turn-based strategy game; however, it cannot be considered a sequel, since it does not continue the story and has many gameplay-related differences.

The battles take place on an isometric screen. Instead of deploying individual space ships and mechs, as it was the case in Remember Me, the player positions human commanders, each controlling several of the aforementioned craft. The player can change formations in order to gain advantage in battle. Commanders are navigated on the screen in turn-based fashion. When an enemy is in range, the player has to choose an attack technique to employ against him. The ensuing battle is then displayed on a separate screen, proceeding automatically.

sample_screenshots.caption: There is even a disco here...
What to do, what to do?..

title: Chō Jikū Yōsai Macross: Skull Leader

description:
Based on the Macross anime, Chō Jikū Yōsai Macross: Love Stories is a direct sequel to Skull Leader; the game continues its story, as the humans on board the SDF-1 Macross continue to fight the Zentradi aliens under the command of Britai Kridanik. Visual style and gameplay system are nearly identical to those of the predecessor: the player deploys unit commanders on an isometric battle field and moves them in turn-based fashion, attacking enemies with mechs and space ships controlled by the commanders.

The sequel features more different human commanders as well as new ship and mech types. The player can choose to play through the main campaign (which includes additional cutscenes and adventure-like menu-based exploration), or directly play any of the three available missions.

sample_screenshots.caption: New types of enemy craft appear

title: Chō Jikū Yōsai Macross: Love Stories

description:
One day, a certain young man notices a little shop labeled "Mirror". When he enters, he encounters a strange, puppet-like woman who calls herself Heine. She shows the young man a puppet that looks like a beautiful young woman, and asks him to touch it. Immediately afterwards, the hero finds himself in a hospital, suffering from amnesia and facing an unknown woman who looks exactly like the puppet. Now he has to find out the truth behind this strange story, and separate dream from reality.

Mirror is a visual novel. Most of the game is composed of text accompanied by still pictures. The game sometimes prompts the player to choose an action or a conversation line out of two or more available ones. Many of these choices, however, do not have a lasting impact on the development of the story. The game contains a few scenes with mild nudity.

sample_screenshots.caption: This is pretty much as erotic as it goes in this game

title: Mirror

description:
A powerful, wealthy and mysterious man named Alex orders his servant to gather sorcerers and cast a spell that would transport him to a quiet town in Japan and make him look like an ordinary teenager. After the transformation, Alex heads to the Fujiwara High School and says he is the new transfer student. The reasons for his actions and the secret of his true identity are gradually revealed as the school is being threatened by evil beings, and heroines with supernatural powers defend it. But in the meantime, the new student must invoke the sexual desires of the town's female inhabitants...

Magical Panic is a Japanese-style adventure with erotic elements. Interaction with the environment is performed by selecting verbs from a menu (such as "Look", "Listen", "Move", etc.), sometimes combining them with objects appearing in a sub-menu. There are no puzzles and no inventory management in the game.
title: Magical Panic

description:
Momo is a princess of a magical world that has come to Earth together with three companions - a bird, a dog, and a monkey - to help humans regain their happiness and bring the two worlds together. She has the appearance of a pretty, cheerful teenage girl, and immediately attracts the attention of a young boy who lives in a quiet town with his biologist father. Together, the two must solve the mysteries of the town, and perhaps find happiness for themselves as well.

Mahō no Princess Minky Momo is based on an anime of the same name. The game is a Japanese-style adventure with a very simple gameplay, making it similar to a visual novel. The player's input is restricted to selecting locations, which automatically advances the story. The game is divided into four chapters, which can be played in any order.
title: Mahō no Princess Minky Momo

description:
Majo-gari means "witch-hunt"; indeed, that is the only thing the protagonist of the game, a young priest living in an unspecified European-like town, thinks about. According to his own words, he believes neither in God nor in the devil; his life is dedicated to one horrifying passion: torturing innocent women...

Majo-gari no Yoru ni is a Japanese-style adventure with very simple gameplay. The player selects locations from a menu; visiting them in specific order usually triggers scenes and advances the story. "Look", "Talk" and similar commands must be sometimes used to lead to the next event. Some of the events will be triggered only if specific conditions are met.

The game is heavy on explicit sexual content, and contains scenes with graphical depictions of rape, torture, and sexual violence. Most of these actions are obligatory and are perpetrated by the player-controlled character.

sample_screenshots.caption: This door should have stayed locked...
The evil priests - one of them is the protagonist

title: Majo-gari no Yoru ni

description:
In 1997, Tokyo was hit by an unseen disaster. Horrifying mutations turned the city into a ruin in a short time. All this was part of a plan concocted by supernatural creatures to bring about what they called a Demonic Destruction. However, a benevolent princess from the same magical realm contacts a simple young girl and tells her that she and other seven chosen humans may stop the catastrophe. Meanwhile, a young man named Gojou is captured by the authorities, but soon thereafter released into the desolate streets of Tokyo with a special mission...

Makyōden is an adventure game; it differs from the vast majority of its Japanese genre brethren by having a third-person view and navigation similar to those found in Western adventures. The interface consists of four icon commands (walk, look, talk, and use) that can be switched with the right mouse button, similarly to Sierra adventures. Despite this unusual feature, the game still resembles Japanese-style adventures in its core: there is no inventory and no puzzles, and the story is advanced simply by exploring areas and talking to characters.
title: Makyōden

description:
The Western kingdom of Endelunia is in grave danger. The forces of Darkness have invaded the country, threatening to conquer it completely and extinguish the power of Light. Princess Armantia appeals to the world's inhabitants to save the kingdom. Eventually, an unlikely hero joins forces with famous female warriors, and together they venture to drive the demonic invaders out of the country.

Marginal Points is a turn-based tactical game with rather simple mechanics. The player controls an army represented by several key characters, which act as unit leaders. The amount of soldiers in each unit is equivalent to individual character hit points. The player navigates the leaders through top-down environment, attacking enemies when they are in weapon range. The actual hostile encounter is displayed on a separate screen, and proceeds automatically. Extended cutscenes advance the story between battles. These scenes may feature dialogue options and even short one-screen point-and-click segments.
title: Marginal Points

description:
A young man named Kenji decides to have a vacation on the beautiful island together with his sister Hiromi. Taking a break from work and worries, the two discover a tourist resort with lovely beaches and high-class hotels. Very soon Kenji finds out that many attractive young women either work on the island or have come there for various reasons. Soon the holiday turns into a never-ending string of sexual escapades - and perhaps one of them will turn into a true romance?

Marine Rouge is a Japanese-style adventure game. The player interacts with the environments by selecting commands, which include Look, Talk, Think, and Move. Object sub-menus appear very rarely; for the most part it is necessary to exhaust all possible choices to complete an event (usually a dialogue) and return to the limited freedom of choosing different locations to visit. Depending on these choices, the game will trigger different scenes, eventually shifting towards different endings.

sample_screenshots.caption: Hentai Stereotype #1: Sexy Office Lady With Glasses

title: Marine Rouge

description:
The kingdom of Franmer lies on the shore of a large sea. One day, a boy from the village of Kos discovered a mysterious ancient stone while diving. The king sends his most renowned specialist to decipher the inscription on the stone. It appears that an evil demon named Gairom has gained possession of sacred orbs that preserve the balance of nature. It is up to the local female warrior Meiria and the magician Faran, daughter of the king's minister, to find a way to retrieve the orbs and defeat Gairom.

Marines: Gairom no Fūin is primarily a puzzle game. The player must use Meiria's unique ability to hurl large orbs that can destroy stone structures. However, Meiria can only shoot in a straight line; in order to change the angle of the shot, the player has to manipulate the orb into a whirlwind, which either occurs naturally or can be produced by positioning other characters of the party at correct angles. Characters can also push stones, and use special abilities to help Meiria achieve her goal.

The game also has light RPG elements. Characters in the party have hit points, and various healing and offensive items can be found during puzzle stages. There are a few dungeons in the game, but they contain no enemies. The few turn-based battles occur as dictated by the plot, and can be won using strategic combinations of physical attacks, magic, and items. There is no leveling system in the game.

Anime-style cutscenes advance the plot between some of the stages. Some of these cutscenes contain explicit nudity and sexual situations.

sample_screenshots.caption: Battle against a big green dude

title: Marines: Gairom no Fūin

description:
Kyosuke, an ordinary Japanese teenager, receives one day a strange invitation to a foreign mansion apparently belonging to a mysterious rich woman. Disregarding the bizarre occurrences accompanying his first impression, Kyosuke agrees to venture into each of the four rooms with colored doors inside the mansion. Each door leads him to a different reality, where he is manifested in different incarnations that allow him to experience various kinds of sexual encounters.

The Masquerade is essentially a visual novel, though with a larger amount of available actions and choices than usually occur in games of this type. One of the stories Kyosuke can access has more pronounced adventure gameplay, with limited menu-based navigation. The others mostly unfold according to choices made by the player. These choices may trigger different scenes or lead to "bad" endings.

sample_screenshots.caption: This incarnation of Kyosuke has two "targets"
Sorry, I need to practice my golf shot

title: The Masquerade

description:
The tribe of demons dwells above the Himalaya mountains. The demon king Zenon is harboring a plan to occupy the Earth and subdue the humans under his yoke. But first, following a demonic ritual, he sends his son to a Japanese private high school. With his side-kick Zabo, who can miraculously change forms and genders, the young demon offspring is incarnated in a human form and has to deal with the hormonal problems most human teenagers suffer from.

Maten Gakuen is a Japanese-style adventure. The player interacts with the environment by choosing commands corresponding to looking, listening, and moving (though in the game they are called "Devil Eye", "Devil Ear", and "Devil Move", respectively). Most of the time selecting these commands prompts the player to choose objects to interacts with from a menu list.

sample_screenshots.caption: The demon heir is riding Zabo... and he will be doing it in more than one way

title: Maten Gakuen: Jigoku no Love Love Daisakusen

description: Memories is a dating-oriented game that can be describe as a light simulation with elements of a visual novel. The game's story premise is abstract: the player character explores a small town, hoping to meet and eventually date young women. The game world consists of photorealistic still pictures of locations; the player's only interaction with the game consists of choosing to travel to these locations and advance the time. Female characters will appear in specific locations at specific times of the day. Several meetings are usually needed to initiate a date. Presents and money can be given to the girls as well. The player can consult a fortune teller and find out, for a fee, about the preferences of specific young women, and locations with high chances of meeting them.

sample_screenshots.caption: These are the "datable" girls... not many yet, indeed

title: Memories: Shiroi Yozora ni Mau Tenshi

description:
Many years ago, in imperial Japan, advances in a mysterious science called "meta-topology" have led to the unexpected prosperity of the Heian era. A special university was founded by the scientists, where researches in bio- and nano-technology were conducted. Since women dominated society during that time, they were the ones imbued with the powers of meta-topology. A series of conflicts between reactionary governments and the "meta-women", as they began calling themselves, continued thousands years into the future. Led by Mayumi Tanaka, president of the astronomy department, a group of young women tries to protect their existence using their remarkable powers.

Metajo is a tactical role-playing game. The game consists of a series of large-scale battles, with cutscenes and dialogues advancing the story. The player controls a group of meta-women, navigating them over top-down battle area. The main characters are controlled by the players, while "nameless" units follow AI routines. Individual battles are displayed on separate screens, and are calculated according to the attributes of the participants. Leveling up occurs after having accumulated a sufficient amount of experience points.
title: Metajo: Furitsu Metatopology Daigaku Fuzoku Joshi Kōkō SP

description: Zai Metajo is the second part of the story described in Metajo. This time, the player controls a group of secret agents within the students committee of the Girls High School attached to the Meta-Topology University, led by Yurika Asano. Endowed with special powers, the girls try to protect the integrity of the school against opponents of meta-topology, as well as possible traitors within their own ranks. Gameplay-wise, this chapter is nearly identical to the first one, relying on the same tactical RPG template with melee attacks and special meta-topology powers. The game offers a few more branching missions, slight interface changes, and the possibility to gamble at a casino.
title: Zai Metajo

description:
During the first few decades of the space era, humanity was able to exist in a relative peace. But soon rogue organizations collectively known as space pirates began to terrorize space stations. This led to a series of violent conflicts. Both sides developed various types of giant mechs operated by human pilots, called "Metal Movers". A special police force was founded to combat the pirates. The young pilot Gingie and his lovely companion Windy must defend the space station and eventually venture into enemy territory.

Metal Mover Jastrike is a top-down shooter. The player navigates a mech through maze-like hostile areas, fighting enemies on the way. Enemies respawn whenever the protagonist re-enters a screen. The mech possesses a basic melee weapon, mid-range laser attack, as well as powerful missile and grenade launchers with limited ammunition. Defeated enemies sometimes drop power-ups which may increase the player character's hit points or shields, eliminate all enemies on screen, etc. Anime-style cutscenes advance the plot between missions. Some of them contain explicit nudity and erotic themes.

sample_screenshots.caption: Hmm, what are those red things?..

title: Metal Mover Jastrike

description: Miho Premium Collection no.003 is dedicated to predominantly sexual experiences of a Japanese young woman named Miho during her work at a hospital as a nurse. The game's story is rather sparse, consisting of various encounters with doctors, staff members, and patients, most of which lead to sexual scenes, often with unsavory medical undertones and torture. The interaction consists of selection of context-specific commands (which usually include "Look" and "Talk"); typically, most or all options have to be depleted before the player can move to the next section of the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: There are also just plain old rape-like scenes... Ahh, Japan! The land where I don't want my wife to travel to
You don't want to know what's going on behind

title: Miho Premium Collection no.003

description:
In the future, humans have invented the time machine. However, criminals soon found a way to manipulate it and hide from the authorities by traveling to the past. As a result, human history began changing itself. In order to put an end to this, a special group called Misty Flash was assembled. Consisting of three young and attractive women - Mai, Yuri, and Miki - the group travels to different time periods, locates criminals, but also liberally enjoys the pleasures of flesh.

Misty Flash is a hybrid of Japanese-style adventure and card-based battles. Short adventure segments feature traditional menu-based interface; typically, the player has to exhaust all options before the next event is triggered. Confrontations against female criminals take the shape of turn-based battles. The player is dealt a deck of cards representing normal attacks, special attacks, healing, as well as buffing up attack power and defense. In addition, each card has a number from 1 to 9; the higher this number is, the stronger is the effect of the card. Battles end with interactive, menu-based lesbian sex scenes.
title: Jikū Sōsakan Pretty Angel: Misty Flash

description: Miwaku no Chōsho is a visual novel with a rather abstract plot. The protagonist, a young man named Shinnosuke, discovers a beautiful mansion, in which apparently a large-scale party is taking place. Determined to meet and enchant some beautiful women, he ventures into the mansion. The rest of the story develops according to the decisions made by the player, which are restricted to choosing one of the several available locations within the mansion, and dialogue prompts during conversations with young women. Depending on these choices, the player will have the opportunity to uncover various scenes involving these women, which eventually lead to sexual intercourse between them and the protagonist. Subsequent plot events and the ending depend on the exact way the player has pursued these relationships.

sample_screenshots.caption: Answer a quiz about the girl

title: Miwaku no Chōsho

description:
After the Principality of Zeon ("Zion" in early transliterations) was defeated by the Earth Federation, some of its members retreated into space, preparing for a large-scale invasion. The moment came when the Federation became weakened after the Gryps War. The Neo-Zeon sent its army onto the Earth, seizing a location in Africa thanks to the help of the Principality loyalists who still remained on Earth. The seemingly never-ending war between the Federation and Zeon has entered a new phase.

Return of Zion is a strategy game based on the anime franchise Gundam. The player controls the forces of the Earth Federation. The game is mission-based; each mission is shaped as a tactical turn-based battle that takes place on a defined map. The player can choose unit types and formations, position them on the map, and then engage in battle against the opposing force. Units may consist of infantry mechas, tanks, and other kinds of machines. One-on-one battles take place on a separate screen, and are actively controlled by the player, who is able to choose the type of weapon to use or retreat from the battle.

sample_screenshots.caption: Plenty of things to choose from...
So the bad guys are called "Zion"? Blaming Jews for all your troubles again?.. :)

title: Mobile Suit Gundam: Return of Zion

description:
Following the establishment of space colonies, tensions between their inhabitants and the Earth Federation gradually increased. The Republic of Zeon pushed for independence, but the Federation applied sanctions to the colony, fearing it would disrupt peace. After a change of leadership, Republic of Zeon became the Principality of Zeon, a despotic, militarized state with a visible intention to achieve independence by any means. Soon the conflict evolved into the deadliest event humanity has ever known - the One Year War.

A Year of War is a strategy game similar to Family Soft's earlier Return of Zion, though from the point of view of Gundam chronology, it is a distant prequel. The gameplay is nearly identical to that of its predecessor: the player navigates units (mostly mecha pilots) in turn-based fashion over the battle field, attacking enemies when they are in the range of the unit's weapons. Like in the previous game, the one-on-one battles are active, the player being able to choose between several kinds of weapons or retreat. In-battle dialogue and cutscenes advance the plot of the game.
title: Mobile Suit Gundam: A Year of War

description:
The events of Stardust Operation takes place in UC (Universal Century) 0083, four years after the devastating One Year War between the Earth federation and the Principality of Zeon. Even though the latter lost the war, rogue organizations affiliated with it continue to pose a threat to the Federation. One of their plans involves dropping a space colony onto the Earth, to damage its food supply. The war has ended, but the hostilities are far from being extinguished.

Stardust Operation is a strategy game based on the events of the anime Mobile Suit Gundam 0083: Stardust Memory. The player takes control of either Federation or Zeon forces, playing through two independent scenarios that evolve linearly, from mission to mission. Each mission is shaped like a tactical battle, during which the player navigates units (mostly mechas) over the battle field in turn-based fashion. Unlike in Family Soft's previous Gundam strategy games, one-on-one battles are automatic; the player chooses the weapon to use in the attack before it initiates. Missions usually involve specific goals, and are interspersed by dialogue and cutscenes.
title: Mobile Suit Gundam 0083: Stardust Operation

description: Moonlight Energy 2 is a sequel to Moon Light Enegy. The game's premise is nearly identical to that of the predecessor: the player controls a high school student named Maki, participating in her lesbian escapades with other students or personnel. Unlike the first game, this is a visual novel with minimal interaction. The player is only occasionally prompted to make a choice for Maki. Some of the scenes, in particular sexual ones, are animated.
title: Moonlight Energy 2

description:
Mujintō Monogatari 2 is a follow-up to Mujintō Monogatari. Like its predecessor, it simulates survival of a group of people on a deserted island - this time, following a ship accident. The basic gameplay is very similar to that of the previous game. The player has to make schedules for the survivors, sending teams to procure necessary supplies such as water, food, light sources, building materials, etc. Only a small part of the island is accessible in the beginning: the player gradually explores it by arranging expeditions. It is possible to manage up to three parties of people, giving each an assignment, which unfolds automatically as the player chooses to complete a day. The survivors' attributes will change depending on the activities chosen by the player.

The game is significantly more story-driven than the first installment. Each of the survivors has his or her own personality, attributes, and unique dialogue lines. Team members will comment on the occurrences, depending on the party formation the player chooses.

sample_screenshots.caption: Hmm, so you are a survivor, too? Nice!..

title: Mujintō Monogatari 2

description:
Mujintō Monogatari 3: A.D.1999 Tokyo is similar in concept to the two previous entries in the series, being a "survival life" simulation game. However, its setting is quite different: rather than getting stranded on a deserted tropical island, the protagonist travels in subway when a terrible earthquake occurs. Climbing out of the underground tunnels, the hero discovers, to his horror, that Tokyo has been nearly destroyed and deserted. Teaming up with other survivors, the protagonist has to explore the ruins and stay alive.

The basic gameplay is similar to that of the two predecessors: the player manages parties of survivors, assigning activities to them (exploring, resting, finding items, etc.), then completing the day and watching these events unfold automatically. Water, food, light, and various materials can be found and collected. It is also possible to craft own items. Scripted events introduce new characters to the team. Hostile encounters may also occur; the player can either choose to fight, retreat, or deal with the potential enemies. There is no active control of the characters during battles.
title: Mujintō Monogatari 3: A.D.1999 Tokyo

description:
Neko Mamma EX is a collection of four small games, unrelated by genre, story, or theme - with the exception of omnipresent adult content:* The longest of the games is a very simple dungeon crawler; the protagonist explores a pseudo-3D maze, fighting randomly appearing enemies in turn-based combat and gradually leveling up. The enemies are pretty young women who undress upon defeat.

  • A so-called "Battle Quiz" is a striptease trivia game in which the player must answer a series of questions within a time limit. After each successful round the virtual female opponent removes a part of her clothes.

  • In the "Cat Race" game the player gambles, betting on various feline-themed attractive women who take part in a running competition. The player can choose between four different courses.

  • A very short Japanese-style adventure game with minimal interface, in which a young girl consults a psychologist and receives a somewhat unusual treatment.

In addition, Neko Mamma EX features a music room, "making of" information, and an art gallery with mostly unrelated, often erotically-themed images.

sample_screenshots.caption: No, this is not an enemy. Rather a friend

title: Neko Mamma EX

description: Net Guardian is a vertically scrolling shoot-em-up that takes place in a futuristic virtual reality. Criminals have found ways to hide within the computer system, and corrupt it through their digital manifestations. The player takes the role of a Net Guardian, an angelic-looking creature equipped with destructive weaponry with the goal of wiping out the criminals. The game's environments switch from abstract computer nodes to anime imagery, sometimes parodying popular video games (for example, one of the levels has scenery and enemies reminiscent of Dragon Quest games). The player can collect power-ups that enhance the current weapon, and also switch between different weapon types. Each stages culminates with a boss battle.

sample_screenshots.caption: Check out the weird anime backgrounds...

title: Net Guardian: Dai Kyō Utage

description: Flame Zapper Kotsujin is a vertically-scrolling sci-fi-themed shoot-em-up. The player controls a fighter spacecraft, advancing through five large levels swarming with enemies (space ships, turrets, tanks, etc.), each culminating with a boss battle. The spacecraft is armed with primary and secondary weapons (fired simultaneously), as well as powerful bomb attacks. Each of these comes in three varieties distinguished by color: red, yellow, and purple. The red group of weapons focuses on spraying fire in different directions; the yellow group contains powerful weapons without covering much of the screen; the purple group is composed of homing lasers and missiles. Power-ups usually stay on screen for a while, changing their color properties.

sample_screenshots.caption: The red weapon in all its glory

title: Flame Zapper Kotsujin

description: Night Gunner is a futuristic shooter completely different from the ZX Spectrum game of the same name. In the future, Earth is under alien invasion, and the player takes the role of its last defender, fending off alien spacecraft. The game is viewed from a first-person perspective; the player can move the aim of the gun, but is otherwise stationary. The goal is to destroy incoming enemy ships by using either beam or more powerful bomb attacks. The gun's energy gradually refills between shots, so it is important to plan ahead and have enough energy for harder battles.
title: Night Gunner: Final Mission

description:
The protagonist of the game is a rather nerdy Japanese teenager named Umechiyo, who impatiently awaits the arrival of his friend, a foreign girl named Piliru who comes to visit Japan. However, it appears that Piliru possesses knowledge of shady activities going on in her homeland, the fictional country of Paru. Pursuers are on their way, and the hero has no choice but protect the girl at all costs.

Nooch is a Japanese-style adventure game. The player interacts with the environment by selecting verb commands (Look, Talk, Think, and others) from a menu, sometimes combining them with objects from a list. On many occasions it is necessary to exhaust all commands to trigger a scene. It is also possible to move between locations via a menu command.
title: Nooch: Abakareta Inbō

description:
Some time has passed since Umechiyo helped the genius girl Piliru to uncover the conspiracy in her homeland Paru. Now Piliru is about to attend a prestigious university in Japan. However, Remy, the leader of the Gilbert organization, will not give up so easily. She enlists the help of a foreign nation and concocts a devious plan. In addition, the relationship between the two heroes doesn't progress well. Umechiyo must find a way to stop Remy and restore peace and order.

Nooch II: Revenge of Remy is a sequel to Nooch: Abakareta Inbō. Gameplay-wise, it is very similar to its predecessor. The player visits various locations by selecting them from a menu, talks to people about various topics, unlocks new information and new locations, and thus advances the story. All the interaction is performed through verb-object menu commands.

sample_screenshots.caption: Umechiyo is not a stranger to voyeurism

title: Nooch II: Revenge of Remy

description:
The mystery of Nooch enters its final phase. Umechiyo and his sweetheart, the genius girl Piliru from the fictional country Paru, are relaxing on the beach when news of another conspiracy surface. The remnants of the Gilbert organization are not willing to give up, and are seeking for a powerful ancient Egyptian artifact. The two heroes must unveil the mystery before their antagonists do.

Nooch III: Saigo no Seisen is the third entry of the Nooch series, and a sequel to Nooch II: Revenge of Remy. Gameplay-wise, it is similar to its predecessors, utilizing standard Japanese-style menu-based interaction and still screens representing locations. However, it also features segments with top-down third-person navigation, which were not present in the previous entries.
title: Nooch III: Saigo no Seisen

description:
Nurse Yū no Mumasensen is an adventure game with a rather cryptic story. The player controls a young nurse named Yū, who finds herself near a secluded military hospital, unable to understand whether she is dreaming or not. She then begins to work at the hospital, becoming more and more intrigued by the events happening in it.

Most of the game is dedicated to selecting locations (hospital rooms) from a map. Repeatedly visiting all the locations eventually triggers events that advance the plot. There is also an icon-based interface with verb commands; however, it is very rudimentary, as there is no possibility to interact with specific objects.

sample_screenshots.caption: A patient is seducing a nurse

title: Nurse Yū no Mumasensen

description:
